Award.AwardTitle: EarthCube Building Blocks: Specifying and Implementing ODSIP, A Data-Service Invocation Protocol
Award.AbstractNarration:
This EarthCube Building Blocks project intends to build ODSIP (Open Data Services Invocation Protocol) to provide a range of open specification in client/server libraries. The core idea is that key parts of EarthCube can be built effectively around clients and servers that employ a common and conceptually rich protocols for data acquisition. The components will be developed 1) an open specification for ODSIP (as a DAP4 extension); 2) a reference implementation of ODSIP in open-source libraries; and
3) client-server demonstrations that show how ODSIP supports three selected geoscience scenarios, each demonstration to be guided by a geoscientist. The three scenarios are: 1) accelerated visualization/analysis of model outputs on non-rectangular
meshes (over coastal North Carolina); 2) dynamic downscaling of climate predictions for regional utility (over Hawaii); and 3) feature-oriented retrievals of satellite imagery (focusing on satellite-derived sea-surface-temperature fronts).

The broader implications of ODSIP include democratizing the use of geoscience data, illustrated in particular by how two of the three geoscience scenarios will benefit emergency managers and inform decision makers about region-specific risks of climate change. The broader implications also include strengthening common understandings across the EarthCube community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project titled Open Data-Service Invocation Protocol (ODSIP) was undertaken to enhance provision of data-as-a-service, terminology that refers to methods whereby scientists and others may employ data without actually possessing them (as downloaded files, e.g.). This applies only when data user and provider share network connectivity, but it is particularly important when data of interest are voluminous and distant, due to Internet bandwidth limitations.

Restating the above, data-as-a-service becomes increasingly valuable as computing and data-creation speeds outstrip networking speeds. Of particular note for ODSIP is the potential application of data-as-a-service to cases where source data are voluminous while user needs may be met with much smaller amounts of information. Such cases are frequent and may arise for various reasons. For example:

  • Geographic Subsets - The source data may cover a large geographic region, whereas the user needs only local coverage; 

  • Statistical Summaries - The source may offer high-resolution detail whereas the user needs only statistical summarization or a subsample;

  • Derived Variables - The source may include a (large) set of variables that have been measured or estimated (in a climate simulation, e.g.), whereas the user may need just a few variables, though some (like maximum rainfall estimates, e.g.) may require derivation.

  • Feature Extraction - Source data organized on a mesh (to represent a continuous variable like surface temperature, e.g.) may mismatch a user's needs topologically, such as when line segments offer the best characterization of the phenomena of interest (perhaps fronts identified by comparing temperatures between adjacent mesh points).

However, addressing all cases can be surprisingly difficult. With geographic subsets, the region of interest may be difficult to extract due to the structure of the source dataset (akin to constructing a triangle from rectangular pieces) and/or the user may require a form of coverage that requires interpolations. With statistical summaries, different users are likely to need differing statistical methods (perhaps percentiles rather than simple means, e.g.). When deriving variables, algebraic or finite-difference formulas likely are required. Finally, feature extraction may entail research-quality algorithms, designed experimentally.  

The ODSIP project sought to address such difficulties via data-as-a-service technology. Specifically, an overarching project goal, per Figure 1, was to demonstrate a Web-based "data-service invocation protocol" (as reflected in the project name). Users would make data-retrieval requests via Uniform Resource Locators (URLs) that include embedded specifications for (potentially complex) pre-retrieval operations.

ODSIP was led by Dave Fulker, Past President of OPeNDAP, a not-for-profit corporation developing Web-based protocols and software for remote data access since 1994, long before invention of the term “data-as-a-service." For ODSIP, Fulker enlisted Unidata—another leading-edge player in modern data-access methods—and three geoscience researchers whose studies could benefit from enhanced data-as-a-service. All issues in the foregoing bullet list were present among ODSIP’s three use cases: i) climate-model downscaling for native-Hawaiian use; ii) storm surge prediction for coastal North Carolina; and iii) sea-surface-temperature front analysis using multiple types of satellite imagery.

Substantial progress was reflected in ODSIP demonstrations mounted for the last two “All Hands” meetings (part of NSF’s EarthCube initiative). The demos included scenarios (difficult without ODSIP advances) showing how users could:

  • Make data requests that included specs for complex pre-retrieval operations.

  • Gain the advantages (namely, quicker response and fewer demands on end-user computers) of reduced data-transfer volumes.

Prior to ODSIP, these scenarios would have required end users to employ vastly more powerful computers with greater data-storage. Importantly, the ODSIP demos were achieved via modest changes to commercial-grade, security-tested, data-serving software, identical to that employed for data access at NASA and similar organizations worldwide. Hence a key ODSIP outcome was to affirm the adaptability of OPeNDAP’s Data Access Protocol (DAP) for invoking a broad range of “server functions” (i.e., pre-retrieval operations).

The ODSIP project showed the practicality of combining data-processing with data-access services. Implemented inside a data-access server, processing services (which we dub “server functions”) are highly efficient because of their data-proximity. Though initial hopes included a compact “algebra” encompassing most users’ server-function needs, a key ODSIP conclusion was: the full range of server-function needs can be met only via full-strength programming in the server’s native language or a powerful scripting language such as Python.

This led to a promising but preliminary demonstration (by Unidata during the 2016 EarthCube All-Hands Meeting) of how an OPeNDAP server might be combined with a Jupyter-notebook scripting environment. Further, our Principal Investigator helped inject notions of Jupyter-like environments (as part of an EarthCube "workbench") into the program's architectural plans.

Building on ODSIP, OPeNDAP has begun planning to join Jupyter with a DAP server to create a friendly Server-Function Development Environment (SFDE). Users of an SFDE could employ Python or other familiar languages to assemble, test and debug server-side workflows, often invoking high-performance function libraries written in the server's native language.
